posts.text: Even if AI surpasses human efficiency to answer any question, humans will still be the ones asking them.

reply_context.text: I've spent nearly the last two decades working as a researcher for hire. Nearly every project, the most important and challenging work is framing the question correctly. This will always be a human endeavor, because passion is human. We have needs that demand satisfaction, and one such is curiosity.

posts.text: I've spent nearly the last two decades working as a researcher for hire. Nearly every project, the most important and challenging work is framing the question correctly. This will always be a human endeavor, because passion is human. We have needs that demand satisfaction, and one such is curiosity.

reply_context.text: Questions arise from experience, from encountering the unexpected or obstacles to be surmounted. AI only even have reason to be curious when we give them those reasons. There will always be a human at the top who owns the question or problem that gives the AI reason to investigate at all.

posts.text: Questions arise from experience, from encountering the unexpected or obstacles to be surmounted. AI only even have reason to be curious when we give them those reasons. The paper you linked identifies a distinction between inferential and descriptive *approaches*, but it falls short of recognizing that there exist contexts in which this distinction isn't one of approach but of definition.

reply_context.text: There exists networks for which the "axiom of connectivity" is useful. These are not the focus of your interest, but they exist and in that domain, community is a descriptive statistic rather than a latent to be inferred.

posts.text: There exists networks for which the "axiom of connectivity" is useful. These are not the focus of your interest, but they exist and in that domain, community is a descriptive statistic rather than a latent to be inferred.

reply_context.text: Not all networks are social. Consider a power distribution network. If there is no path between two nodes, electricity can't flow between them. And yet it is still useful to analyze the modularity of this network to e.g. probe robustness.

posts.text: Not all networks are social. Consider a power distribution network. If there is no path between two nodes, electricity can't flow between them. And yet it is still useful to analyze the modularity of this network to e.g. probe robustness.

reply_context.text: lol I'm very much not. you are just conflating a strictly mathematical notion of community structure as a useful descriptive statistic with notions of community that are more useful to social science research.

posts.text: lol I'm very much not. you are just conflating a strictly mathematical notion of community structure as a useful descriptive statistic with notions of community that are more useful to social science research.

Your use of community: "given nodes are members of a shared community, how will that manifest in the observed relationships between them?"

The naive use you are taking issue with: "given observed relationships, how can we characterize that structure descriptively?"

reply_context.text:
I did, and you are making my point for me. If you are using a GENERATIVE model to build your network, nodes must have latent variables.

You are using "community" as a descriptor of an a priori property of nodes. The strictly graph theory view treats it as an a posteriori descriptor of structure.

posts.text:
I did, and you are making my point for me. If you are using a GENERATIVE model to build your network, nodes must have latent variables.

You are using "community" as a descriptor of an a priori property of nodes. The strictly graph theory view treats it as an a posteriori descriptor of structure.

Rephrasing: your issue is really with blindly adopting graph-theoretic methods without reviewing whether or not their assumptions are appropriate. This "axiom" is not remotely unfounded,  it's just not applicable to the kinds of networks you're interested in.

reply_context.text: Interested to see an example network where components are disconnected and nodes don't have attributes byeond connectivity, but it is evident from the network topology that two disconnected components should be assigned to the same community.

posts.text: Interested to see an example network where components are disconnected and nodes don't have attributes byeond connectivity, but it is evident from the network topology that two disconnected components should be assigned to the same community.

reply_context.text: Conspicuously missing from your post: if this axiom is not necessary, what does it even mean for two nodes to be members of the same community? If all we have is connectivity information and two components are disconnected, what is your justification for placing them in the same community?

posts.text: Conspicuously missing from your post: if this axiom is not necessary, what does it even mean for two nodes to be members of the same community? If all we have is connectivity information and two components are disconnected, what is your justification for placing them in the same community?

reply_context.text: If the nodes share similarity in a feature space, we can meaningfully assign them to a community without concern for network topology. If all we have is topology, I'd contend that a meaningful definition of shared community membership requires intra-member connectivity.

posts.text: If the nodes share similarity in a feature space, we can meaningfully assign them to a community without concern for network topology. If all we have is topology, I'd contend that a meaningful definition of shared community membership requires intra-member connectivity.

reply_context.text: It comes from graph theory. Your contention here presumes a network where nodes have attributes. If the only attributes on the network are the node connectivity, there is zero rationale for assigning two nodes to the same community that have no path between them.

posts.text: It comes from graph theory. Your contention here presumes a network where nodes have attributes. If the only attributes on the network are the node connectivity, there is zero rationale for assigning two nodes to the same community that have no path between them.
